Overview.Summary: The 2016 Romanian legislative election (Event) took place on December 11, 2016 (1, 3). The election was closely followed as it would determine the next Prime Minister and ruling party (1). There was also a lot of attention on the control of the state legislature (2, 7). The results of the election were certified by Congress on January 6, 2017 (9). The newly elected members of the chamber of deputies of Romania included a majority of women (6).

Timeline.Text: The 2016 Pennsylvania House of Representatives election takes place, with all 203 seats up for election.
The results of the 2016 United States elections are officially certified by Congress, with Republicans retaining their majorities in both the House and Senate.
The San Diego Union Tribune endorses a Democrat candidate for the first time in its 148-year history, and for the first time in 126 years, the Chicago Sun-Times also endorses a Democrat candidate.
Romanian voters participate in the 2016 legislative elections, deciding on a new Prime Minister and the ruling party.
The MCC issues instructions regarding the biennial and bye-elections to the Legislative Councils in Romania.
Congress formally certifies the results of the 2016 United States elections, officially declaring Donald Trump as the next President.
Protests against government corruption continue in Romania, with demonstrators demanding action from the government.

The 2016 election was known for its chaotic and dramatic scenes, including a recount initiated by Green Party nominee Jill Stein (10).

The Green Party's Jill Stein raises $6 million for presidential election recounts.

Journalists and analysts reflect on the unexpected victory of Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Romanian legislative election resulted in a victory for the Social Democratic Party (PSD) (2,3,4,5,6,8,10). Sorin Grindeanu, the former telecommunications minister, was nominated as the prime minister by the PSD (4). The election was held following a year of technocrat government (8) and a corruption scandal that ousted the previous prime minister (3,5,6,7,9). The PSD's victory marks a return to power for the party after a landslide victory (2).

Timeline.Text: Exit polls show that the Social Democratic Union is set to win the Romanian legislative election.
The Social Democrats win a landslide victory in the parliamentary elections.
Final results show that the Social Democrats and their allies have won a majority in both houses of parliament.
Sorin Grindeanu is nominated as prime minister by the Social Democrats.
The Romanian government faces nationwide protests over a controversial decree to decriminalize official misconduct.
Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu survives a no-confidence vote in the midst of nationwide unrest.

Overview.Summary: In the 2016 Romanian legislative election, the Social Democratic Party (PSD) won 45.47% of the vote in the Chamber of Deputies and 45.67% in the Senate (6). The PSD, along with the National Liberal Party (PNL) and a Hungarian minority party, will form the coalition government (7). The new Prime Minister, Sorin Grindeanu, was appointed by President Klaus Iohannis (10). Over 7 million Romanians voted in the election (9). The electoral law was modified in July 2015, resulting in a lower chamber with 308 members (1). The PSD's victory marks their return to power after a corruption scandal forced their previous prime minister out (3,5). The PNL had set a goal to win a quarter of the seats in the Chamber (6). The total number of seats in the parliament is 465 (4).

Timeline.Text: Despite a corruption scandal, the Social Democratic Union is poised to win back power in Romania.
The centre-left Social Democratic Party wins the Romanian legislative election with 45% of the seats in both houses of parliament.
The Social Democratic Party (PSD) led by Liviu Dragnea easily wins the parliamentary elections.
The final results of the Romanian parliamentary election are announced, with the PSD winning 45.47% of the vote.
Social-democrat Sorin Grindeanu is named the new Prime Minister of Romania by President Klaus Iohannis.

Overview.Summary: The 2016 Romanian legislative election saw the victory of the Social Democratic Party (PSD) with 45% of the seats in both houses of parliament (1,7,13). Their leader, Liviu Dragnea, easily drew ahead in the election (11). The election was held on December 11 and saw the PSD win 45.47% of the vote in the Chamber of Deputies and 45.67% in the Senate (11,18). Despite a corruption scandal, the PSD is expected to return to power (9). The election was also monitored by the OSCE (4,15).

Timeline.Text: Romanians vote in parliamentary elections, with the centre-left Social Democratic Party and the liberal centre-right Alliance of Liberals and Democrats Party expected to form a coalition government.
The Social Democratic Party wins a majority of seats in both houses of parliament, paving the way for its return to power.
The Social Democratic Party's victory is seen as a blow to anti-corruption efforts in Romania.
Liviu Dragnea, leader of the Social Democratic Party, claims victory in the parliamentary elections.
Sevil Shhaideh, a member of the Social Democratic Party, is nominated as the first female Muslim prime minister of Romania.
Romania's annual inflation rate ends 2016 at -0.5%, the lowest in the country's history.
Romania's Prime Minister Sorin Grindeanu survives a no-confidence vote amid nationwide protests over the government's attempt to weaken corruption laws.
The Romanian legislative election of 2016 is commemorated as Romania's centre-left Social Democratic Party wins 45% of the seats in both houses of parliament.
The Embassy will not be providing voting services for the ACT Legislative Election. Those people enrolled to vote in the ACT may apply for a postal vote at the Elections ACT website.
The Romanian electoral law is modified, reducing the number of members in the lower chamber and allowing voters to cast their ballots by post.
Jovenel Moise wins the Haitian presidential election.
